'''Behavioral ethics''' is a new field of [[social science|social scientific]] research that seeks to understand how people actually behave when confronted with ethical dilemmas.<ref>Bazerman, Max H. and Tenbrunsel, Ann E. "Blind Spots: Why we fail to do what's right and what to do about it". Princeton University Press, 2011, p. 4.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Intro to Behavioral Ethics - Ethics Unwrapped - UT Austin|url = http://ethicsunwrapped.utexas.edu/video/introduction-to-behavioral-ethics|website = Ethics Unwrapped|accessdate = 2015-11-04|language = en-US}}</ref> It refers to behavior that is judged according to generally accepted norms of behavior.<ref>Trevino, Linda K., Weaver, Gary R., and Reynolds, Scott J. "Behavioral Ethics in Organizations: A review". Journal of Management, 2006, p. 952.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = June 27, 2014 ~ Behavioral Ethics {{!}} June 27, 2014 {{!}} Religion & Ethics NewsWeekly {{!}} PBS|url = https://www.pbs.org/wnet/religionandethics/2014/06/27/june-27-2014-behavioral-ethics/23445/|website = Religion & Ethics NewsWeekly|accessdate = 2015-11-05|language = en-US}}</ref>
== Behavioral ethics in different fields ==
=== Behavioral ethics and education === In ethics teaching and research, ethics is arguably the "next big thing" because its �investigation agenda has generated many knowledge on why and how people choose and act when being confronted with ethical subject, which was unknown previously.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://ethicsunwrapped.utexas.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Teaching-Behavioral-Ethics-by-Robert-A.-Prentice.pdf|title = Teaching behavioral ethics|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Robert|first = Prentice}}</ref>
=== Behavioral Ethics and Rational Actor Model === Philosophical views about morality has been supported traditionally by theoretical reasoning and introspection, with at best passing reference to actual human behavior. Models of human morality advanced by behavioral ethics based on the fact that morality is a new and still developing quality of the evolutionary dynamic that leads to our species.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.umass.edu/preferen/gintis/BehavioralEthics.pdf|title = Behavioral Ethics|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Herbert|first = Gintis}}</ref>
=== Behavioral Ethics Meets Behavioral Law and Economics === Clarifying the difference between behavioral law and economics(BEL) and behavioral ethics(BE) is of importance. Compared to BLE, BE has reduced its ability of influencing broad legal academic circles. In addition, unlike BLE, BE was advanced as piece of the management literature, which is less related to legal scholarship than BLE is, and thus less likely to have impact on it.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Behavioral Ethics Meets Behavioral Law and Economics|ssrn = 2226711|date = 2013-10-03|location = Rochester, NY|first = Yuval|last = Feldman}}</ref>
=== Behavioral Ethics and Justice === Behavioral ethics researchers have found the relationship between employees' justice perceptions and also, ethical and unethical behavior. In the 1990s, organizational justice became one of the most studied organizational themes. The term organizational justice is created by Greenberg(1987) to involve employee's perception of organizational events, policies, and practices as being fair or not fair. Classic work on distributive justice, procedural justice and interactional justice has been built. This research has focused on theoretical advance and empirical testing about the formation of justice judgements as well as the result of these justice evaluation. Justice and injustice perception have been related to an extensive variety of employee attitudes and behaviors consisted of trust, satisfaction, turnover and plenty of opposite formal negative behaviors such as theft and unethical behaviors which are more common.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.nipc.ir/uploads/m099_12051.pdf|title = Behavioral Ethics in Organizations: A Review|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==Research== There are experiments that can be linked to behavioral ethics. The [[Trolley problem]] and the [[Prisoner's dilemma]] both place individuals in decision-making situations that carry ethical questions. In each, an individual is asked to make a decision that affects another person. In the [[prisoner's dilemma]], the principles of [[Reciprocity (social psychology)]] and [[Cooperation]] come into play, but not all who participate behave in the same manner. In the [[Trolley problem]] an individual has to choose which group of people to save. Both of these experiments shed light on how people behave when confronted with ethical dilemmas.
== The impact of behavioral ethics == If firms are able to utilize the principles of behavioral psychology to alter consumer's behavior and thus increase sales and governments can change people's behavior and hence promote policy target using those same principles, then individuals and their employers can apply related principles of behavioral ethics to promote ethical behavior in the company and in society.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Behavioral Ethics: Can It Help Lawyers (and Others) Be Their Best Selves?|ssrn = 2424249|date = 2014-04-12|location = Rochester, NY|first = Robert A.|last = Prentice}}</ref>
== Example of Unethical behavior in Business == According to an article in the Chron.com, examples of unethical behavior in business an environment can include:<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://smallbusiness.chron.com/examples-unethical-behavior-workplace-10092.html|title=Examples of Unethical Behavior in the Workplace|last=|first=|date=January 31, 2018|work=Chron.com|access-date=2018-04-16|language=en}}</ref>
# Deliberate Deception # Violation of Conscience # Failure to Honor Commitments # Unlawful Conduct # Disregard of Company Policy
These behaviors are mostly based on different rights that we all have in society and therefore have in work environments as well. Usually each company have its own set of policy but there are some common ones as well.
== Examples of Ethical Behavior in Business Meetings == At most business conference, employees are required to report on the progress of their missions. It can lead to an ethical dilemma because they may report their performance better than it is due to external pressure.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Examples of Ethical Behavior in Business Meetings|url = http://smallbusiness.chron.com/examples-ethical-behavior-business-meetings-21680.html|website = Small Business - Chron.com|accessdate = 2015-11-05}}</ref>
== Unethical behavior == Unethical behavior is an action that falls outside of what is thought morally appropriate for a person, a job or a company. Individuals can act unethically, as can businesses, professionals and politicians.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Examples of Unethical Behavior|url = http://examples.yourdictionary.com/examples-of-unethical-behavior.html|website = YourDictionary|accessdate = 2015-11-05}}</ref>
=== Unethical behavior in business === Ethics can be defined as going beyond what is legal and doing right things, even no one is paying attention to. So unethical behavior in business is about actions that don't obey the acceptable criterion of business operations, failing to do right things in each condition.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Unethical Behavior in Business: Definition & Examples - Video & Lesson Transcript {{!}} Study.com|url = http://study.com/academy/lesson/unethical-behavior-in-business-definition-examples.html|website = Study.com|accessdate = 2015-11-05}}</ref>

The term '''behavioural synchrony''' refers to the ability of a group of agents to coordinate collective action efficiently, a concept originally introduced by a series of empirical animal<ref>{{Cite journal|last = King|first = Andrew J.|last2 = Cowlishaw|first2 = Guy|date = 2009-12-01|title = All together now: behavioural synchrony in baboons|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S000334720900414X|journal = Animal Behaviour|volume = 78|issue = 6|pages = 1381–1387|doi = 10.1016/j.anbehav.2009.09.009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last = Copeland|first = Jonathan|last2 = Moiseff|first2 = Andrew|title = The occurrence of synchrony in the North American fireflyPhotinus carolinus (Coleoptera: Lampyridae)|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01989366|journal = Journal of Insect Behavior|language = en|volume = 8|issue = 3|pages = 381–394|doi = 10.1007/BF01989366|issn = 0892-7553}}</ref> and human<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last = Cohen|first = Emma E. A.|last2 = Ejsmond-Frey|first2 = Robin|last3 = Knight|first3 = Nicola|last4 = Dunbar|first4 = R. I. M.|date = 2010-02-23|title = Rowers' high: behavioural synchrony is correlated with elevated pain thresholds|url = http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/6/1/106|journal = Biology Letters|language = en|volume = 6|issue = 1|pages = 106–108|doi = 10.1098/rsbl.2009.0670|issn = 1744-9561|pmc = 2817271|pmid = 19755532}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last = Baimel|first = Adam|last2 = Severson|first2 = Rachel L.|last3 = Baron|first3 = Andrew S.|last4 = Birch|first4 = Susan A. J.|date = 2015-06-23|title = Enhancing "theory of mind" through behavioral synchrony|journal = Frontiers in Psychology|volume = 6|doi = 10.3389/fpsyg.2015.00870|issn = 1664-1078|pmc = 4477228|pmid = 26157415}}</ref> studies, and modelling papers in animals,<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Ermentrout|first = B.|title = An adaptive model for synchrony in the firefly Pteroptyx malaccae|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00164052|journal = Journal of Mathematical Biology|language = en|volume = 29|issue = 6|pages = 571–585|doi = 10.1007/BF00164052|issn = 0303-6812}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last = Sumpter|first = D. J. T.|date = 2006-01-29|title = The principles of collective animal behaviour|url = http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/361/1465/5|journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|language = en|volume = 361|issue = 1465|pages = 5–22|doi = 10.1098/rstb.2005.1733|issn = 0962-8436|pmc = 1626537|pmid = 16553306}}</ref> and humans.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last = Dávid-Barrett|first = Tamás|last2 = Dunbar|first2 = R. I. M.|date = 2012-09-07|title = Cooperation, behavioural synchrony and status in social networks|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022519312002330|journal = Journal of Theoretical Biology|volume = 308|pages = 88–95|doi = 10.1016/j.jtbi.2012.05.007}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last = Dávid-Barrett|first = T.|last2 = Dunbar|first2 = R. I. M.|date = 2013-08-22|title = Processing power limits social group size: computational evidence for the cognitive costs of sociality|url = http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/280/1765/20131151|journal = Proc. R. Soc. B|language = en|volume = 280|issue = 1765|pages = 20131151|doi = 10.1098/rspb.2013.1151|issn = 0962-8452|pmc = 3712454|pmid = 23804623}}</ref> The agents are trying to coordinate collective action on a social network in which the communication is restricted to dyadic information flows.
== Research background == The behavioural synchrony model universe relies on two key sets of assumptions. The first set of assumptions concerns the structure of the network: it is assumed that (a) the agents form a [[social network]] in a way that the network is connected, i.e., all agents have some direct or indirect connection to every other agent, and [[Sparse network|sparse]], i.e., the network the agents form is not fully connected; and (b) all agents have the same [[Degree (graph theory)|network degree]], i.e., every agent is connected to the same number of other agents. In network science terms, the assumption is that the agents form a ''k''-regular ''n''-sized connected graph, where ''k'' is the degree of the agents, and ''n'' is the number of agents. The second set of assumptions concern the nature of coordination: it is assumed that the content of the coordination is not important (independent of whether it is a linguistic cue, cultural identity, or simple compass direction), but is set up in a way that the agents cannot guess the location of the final convergence point of the group from any individual information exchange. These assumptions cause coordination to slow, where the speed is dependent on the network structure, and the agents need to think hard during the coordination process.
The behavioural synchrony approach introduced behavioural realism into social network coordination, via assuming that the network structure is similar to actual human groups, and by making the coordination process not-trivial, and thus making the modelled group processes reflect [[Human behavior|human behaviour]]. The behavioural synchrony approach has led to a range of human application, especially concerning the human evolutionary past: * Synchronisation of physical activity, especially of exertion, contributes to group bonding.<ref name=":0" /> * Social hierarchy can be beneficial for collective action,<ref name=":1" /> but can lead to stratification and elite delineation that is harmful for collective action.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last = Dávid-Barrett|first = Tamás|last2 = Dunbar|first2 = R. I. M.|date = 2013-10-22|title = Social elites can emerge naturally when interaction in networks is restricted|url = http://beheco.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2013/10/21/beheco.art085|journal = Behavioral Ecology|language = en|pages = art085|doi = 10.1093/beheco/art085|issn = 1045-2249}}</ref> * Supernatural beliefs, especially when mediated by a priestly cast, can increase the efficiency of large but not small groups.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Dávid-Barrett|first = Tamás|last2 = Carney|first2 = James|date = 2016-10-01|title = The deification of historical figures and the emergence of priesthoods as a solution to a network coordination problem|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/2153599X.2015.1063001|journal = Religion, Brain & Behavior|volume = 6|issue = 4|pages = 307–317|doi = 10.1080/2153599X.2015.1063001|issn = 2153-599X}}</ref> * Increased brain size during human evolution only leads to increased cooperation efficiency if associated with increased complexity of communication, in particular with language.<ref name=":2" /> * All lasting human societies must have found a solution to regulate social inequality.<ref name=":3" />

'''Bellingcat''' (also rendered '''bell¿ngcat''') is a website founded by the British [[citizen journalist]] [[Eliot Higgins]]. Bellingcat publishes the findings of citizen journalist investigations into war zones and the [[criminal underworld]]. The site's contributors also publish guides to their techniques, as well as [[case studies]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/about/|title=About - bellingcat|publisher=}}</ref>
Bellingcat began as an investigation of the use of weapons in the [[Syrian civil war]]. It first received international attention with its analysis of forged data on satellite images of the downing of the [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17]] during the still ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in eastern Ukraine]].
==Name== The name derives from the idiom "[[belling the cat]]", which comes from a medieval fable about mice who discuss how to make a cat harmless. One suggests hooking a bell around his neck, and all the mice support the idea but none is willing to do it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/To+bell+the+cat |title=To bell the cat - definition of To bell the cat by The Free Dictionary |website=Thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2016-12-24}}</ref>
==History== In March 2012, Eliot Higgins started a blog under the pseudonym Brown Moses, through which he published his research into video footage of the [[Syrian Civil War]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://brown-moses.blogspot.de/2012_03_01_archive.html |title=Brown Moses Blog: March 2012 |website=Brown-moses.blogspot.de |date= |accessdate=2016-12-24}}</ref> He looked at hundreds of these short clips on the Internet, localized them, and examined details of the weapons used. As a result, Higgins was able to demonstrate that the Syrian regime was using [[cluster munition]]s and [[chemical weapon]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://qz.com/254405/kickstarter-funded-journalists-found-an-isil-training-camp-using-google-earth-and-bing-maps/|title=Kickstarter-funded journalists found an ISIL training camp using Google Earth and Bing Maps|date=24 August 2014|quote=for proving Syria was using chemical weapons from his bedroom in Leicester}}</ref> In 2013, Higgins linked the significant [[chemical attack]] in [[Ghouta]] (the [[Ghouta chemical attack]]) to [[Bashar al-Assad]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cjr.org/business_of_news/bellingcat_brown_moses.php|title=Watch out for Bellingcat|work=Columbia Journalism Review|access-date=2017-03-19|language=en}}</ref>
Once Bellingcat was launched, major ground was covered over the course of its first investigation, the downing of [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17]] (MH17). Bellingcat concluded that the downing was initiated by the Russian military; this was later confirmed by the Joint Investigation Team (JIT), which found in a report dated 25 May 2018 that the downing of MH17 was initiated by the Russian military.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.om.nl/onderwerpen/mh17-vliegramp/@103183/update-criminal/|title=Update in criminal investigation MH17 disaster|publisher=}}</ref> In other notable investigations using [[Google Earth]], analysts from Bellingcat said that they had discovered the coordinates of an [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] training camp, as well as the site where an American journalist was killed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1278239551/bellingcat-the-home-of-online-investigations|title=Bellingcat: the home of online investigations|website=Kickstarter|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-19}}</ref>
[[Kristyan Benedict]], an [[Amnesty International]] campaign manager, told ''[[The New Yorker]]'' in 2013 that many organisations had analysts but that Higgins was faster than many established investigation teams.<ref>{{cite web|last=Batuman |first=Elif |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/11/25/rocket-man-2 |title=Rocket Man |publisher=[[The New Yorker]] |date=23 November 2013|accessdate=24 December 2016}}</ref>
Higgins launched the Bellingcat platform in 2014 with the help of private donations received through the crowdfunding platform [[Kickstarter]].<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Beauman |first1=Ned |title=How to Conduct an Open-Source Investigation, According to the Founder of Bellingcat |work=[[The New Yorker]] |date=2018-08-30 |url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/how-to-conduct-an-open-source-investigation-according-to-the-founder-of-bellingcat |issn=0028-792X |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Half of funding comes from grants and donations, the other half from running workshops training people in the art of open-source investigations.<ref name=millard>{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/uk-leads-way-skripal-case-online-savvy-033611412.html |title=UK site leads the way in Skripal case with online savvy |work=AFP |via=[[Yahoo! News]] |author=Robin Millard |date=September 29, 2018 |accessdate=September 30, 2018}}</ref> For example, Bellingcat has received grants from Google Digital News Initiative, Adessium, and the [[Open Society Foundations]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Eliot |first1=Higgins |title=Bellingcat: the home of online investigations |url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1278239551/bellingcat-the-home-of-online-investigations |website=Kickstarter |accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref> The organisation publishes guides on how to analyse data and how to create reports, such as "How to Scrape Interactive Geospacial Data" and "How to Identify Burnt Villages by Satellite Imagery".<ref name=millard/>
As of 2018, the company has four full-time staff plus Higgins, 11 members of its investigation team and 60 contributors.<ref name=millard/> The office is in [[Leicester]].<ref name=millard/>
==Notable cases== ===War in eastern Ukraine=== {{main|War in Donbass}} On 21 December 2016, a report by Bellingcat was published which analyses the use of Russian artillery in the summer of 2014 against Ukrainian villages.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/ArtilleryAttacks_withCover_EmbargoNote.pdf |format=PDF |title=Putin's Undeclared War : Summer 2014 : Russian Artillery Strikes Against Ukraine |author1=Sean Case |author2=Klement Anders |website=Bellingcat.com |accessdate=2016-12-24}}</ref>
===MH17=== [[File:MH17 map-lv.svg|thumb|351x351px|Route of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 on July 17, 2014 from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur.]]
On July 17, 2014 [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17]], a passenger flight from [[Amsterdam]] to [[Kuala Lumpur]], was shot down while flying over eastern Ukraine. All 283 passengers and 15 crew members died after the Boeing 777 was hit by a burst of "high-energy objects".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/09/world/europe/netherlands-ukraine-mh17-report/index.html |title=Report: MH17 hit by burst of 'high-energy objects' |author=Jethro Mullen|publisher=CNN|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref>
In a press conference, Russian officials blamed the flight's destruction on Ukrainian forces and presented radar data, expert testimony and a satellite image. The radar data that showed another aircraft in the vicinity of MH17 was debunked as falling debris from MH17 by experts. A Spanish air traffic controller in Kiev gave interviews that stated that two Ukrainian fighter jets followed the Malaysian plane but the Spanish Embassy later said that there was no Spanish air traffic controller at either of Kiev's airports. The satellite image showed an aircraft firing on the airliner but Bellingcat exposed the photo as a composite of Google images, with the Malaysian airline logo even being misplaced.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2015/07/03/meet-eliot-higgins-putins-mh17-nemesis-345485.html|title=Meet Eliot Higgins, Putin’s MH17 Nemesis|author=Maxim Tucker |date=2015-06-22|website=Newsweek|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref>
On November 9, 2014, the Bellingcat MH17 Investigation team published a report titled “MH17: Source of the Separatists’ Buk”. Based on evidence from open sources, primarily social media, the report links a Buk missile launcher that was filmed and photographed in eastern Ukraine on July 17 to the downing of the MH17 flight. The 35 page report, including photographs and maps, details the movements of the Buk in eastern Ukraine on July 17, evidence that the Buk originated from the [[53rd Anti-Aircraft Rocket Brigade]] in Kursk, Russia, along with a convoy headed towards the Ukrainian border, and the activity of the vehicles seen in the same convoy after July 17.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/Origin-of-the-Separatists-Buk-A-Bellingcat-Investigation1.pdf|title=Origin of the Seperatists' Buk|last=Bellingcat|first=|date=November 9, 2014|website=Bellingcat|access-date=}}</ref> This report was later echoed by the Dutch-led international [[Joint Investigation Team]]. The head of the Netherlands’ National Crime Squad, said they officially concluded that the missile that shot down MH17 "is from the 53rd anti-aircraft missile brigade from Kursk in the Russian Federation".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/investigators-russian-military-missile-downed-flight-mh17/2018/05/24/5b807ac2-5f34-11e8-b656-236c6214ef01_story.html?noredirect=on|title=Probe: Missile that downed MH17 came from Russia-based unit|date=24 May 2018|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref>
In June 2015, Bellingcat published evidence that Russia had used [[Adobe Photoshop]] to manipulate satellite images of the MH17 disaster. Image forensics expert Jens Kriese of Germany maintained that Bellingcat's report used invalid methods to reach its conclusion.<ref name=ders>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/expert-criticizes-allegations-of-russian-mh17-manipulation-a-1037125.html |title=Expert Criticizes Allegations of Russian MH17 Manipulation |work=Der Spiegel |author=Jens Kriese |date=June 4, 2015 |accessdate=June 11, 2017}}</ref> In a follow-up report, Bellingcat published crowdfunded satellite imagery and further analysis that supported their claim.<ref name=zeitde>{{cite web |url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/ausland/2015-06/bellingcat-russland-mh17-satellitenfotos-manipulation |title=Bellingcat kontert Kritik mit neuen Satellitenbildern |work=Zeit Online |language=German |author= |date=12 June 2015 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
On December 20, 2017, Bellingcat published an article focusing on a section of the 2017 [[Intelligence and Security Committee]] report, which categorically stated that the British stance on the MH17 incident was that Russian forces were behind the orchestration and implementation of a plan to shoot down an aircraft. Whether the target was the MH17 passenger jet is not defined.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Toler|first1=Aric|title=British Intelligence Report Confirms Russian Military Origin of MH17 Murder Weapon|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2017/12/20/british-intelligence-report-confirms-russian-military-origin-mh17-murder-weapon/|website=Bellingcat|accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ISCP Annual Report 2016-2017|url=https://b1cba9b3-a-5e6631fd-s-sites.googlegroups.com/a/independent.gov.uk/isc/files/2016-2017_ISC_AR.pdf?attachauth=ANoY7cqS8WVJqzXucCjkPcD1PkT4M4RJspBV9tHBYEJAZLobTFw2rG67hpLh55zoZsZ9_9Xrmtqiq4CzbwmhAUpzCTh3AW-lBjOdmWFYJds1-EYzBgJGRmPWubVpg_Yl0SrMUrYTcKGn-8HtPvf5AARiu60msxtT2SpjJfdv78EEeqkINZBUythVem1KHFtKbbziZLQNdiiOymaCinv1pUa1FIpSVaHOkjNwmyfFteiMvnTRX00Qz_0%3D&attredirects=0}}</ref>
===Syrian Civil War=== {{main|Syrian Civil War}}
[[File:ISIS (Grey) Territory Change 2014-2016.gif|thumb|ISIS (grey) territory change 2014–2016]] Beginning in March 2011 after political protests turned violent,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-12791738l|title=Middle East unrest: Three killed at protest in Syria |publisher=BBC News|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref> the Syrian Civil War has been an ongoing conflict between the [[Syrian Arab Republic]], [[Syrian Opposition]], [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]], and [[List of armed groups in the Syrian Civil War|other combatants]]. Bellingcat reports primarily analyse the factions at war, and what weapons and armor they utilize, as well as news that would normally go unreported by the mainstream media. Bellingcat utilizes a network of contributors who specialize in open source and social media investigation, and creates guides and case studies so others may learn to do the same.<ref>{{Cite web|url= https://www.bellingcat.com/about/|title= About |last=Higgins|first=Elliot|website=Bellingcat|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref>
In April 2014, Bellingcat published extensive evidence of chemical weapons being used on Syrian civilians, including children. Collecting and analysing video footage from local sources which apparently showed parts of [[chlorine]] cylinders, Higgins said that while the contents of the cylinders could not be verified "the injuries depicted in the videos all appear to be consistent with chemical exposure".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.vice.com/article/syria-is-accused-of-suffocating-its-citizens-with-chlorine-bombs|title=Syria Is Accused of Suffocating Its Citizens with Chlorine Bombs|date=23 April 2014|work=Vice News}}</ref>
In June 2016, Bellingcat published an article showing the use of [[cluster munition]]s were being used against the [[New Syrian Army]], in clear violation of the [[Convention on Cluster Munitions]]. Bellingcat provided photographic evidence from firsthand sources that the munitions used were identical to those used by the [[Russian Armed Forces|Russian Military]] .<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/mena/2016/06/21/al-tanf-bombing-russia-assisted-isis-attacking-us-backed-fsa-group-cluster-bombs/|title=The al-Tanf Bombing: How Russia Assisted ISIS by Attacking an American Backed FSA Group with Cluster Bombs|last=Komar|first=Rao|website=Bellingcat|access-date=2017-03-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008185930/https://www.bellingcat.com/news/mena/2016/06/21/al-tanf-bombing-russia-assisted-isis-attacking-us-backed-fsa-group-cluster-bombs/|archive-date=2016-10-08|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In February 2017, Bellingcat published an article detailing how rudimentary [[Quadcopter|drones]] were being used by [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIS]] to drop explosives onto opposition targets. Analysing footage from Twitter and other social media platforms, it was discovered that the drones were dropping modified [[40 mm grenade|40mm grenades]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/uncategorized/2017/02/10/death-drone-bombs-caliphate/|title=Death From Above: The Drone Bombs of the Caliphate |last=Waters|first=Nick |website=Bellingcat|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref>
Bellingcat also does extensive reporting into attacks that are not openly claimed by combatants.
In September 2016, Bellingcat released a fact-checking article in response to Russia denying the bombing of hospitals in Syria. The article analysed footage from YouTube and images from Facebook, cross referencing them with areas that were confirmed to be attacked by Russian forces. The article reported that the hospital in question was within the area under Russian attack, although Russia denies these claims.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/mena/2016/09/01/fact-checking-russias-claim-didnt-bomb-5-year-old-syria/|title=Fact-Checking Russia’s Claim that It Didn’t Bomb a 5-Year-Old in Syria |last=Al-Khatib|first=Hady|website=Bellingcat|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref>
In March 2017, Bellingcat published an investigative report on [[2017 al-Jina mosque airstrike|the bombing of a mosque in Aleppo]] that killed over 50 civilians. The article included photographs of the remnants of the bomb used, and showed that the piece was identical to that of similar bombs used by the US military.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/mena/2017/03/16/us-missile-remains-reportedly-recovered-from-site-of-aleppo-mosque-bombing/|title=CONFIRMED: US Responsible for ‘Aleppo Mosque Bombing’ |last=Triebert|first=Christiaan|website=Bellingcat|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref>
===Yemeni Civil War===
Bellingcat published that in the [[2018 Hajjah Governorate airstrike]] the bomb was made by the American company [[Raytheon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/mena/2018/04/27/american-made-bomb-used-airstrike-yemen-wedding/|title=American-Made Bomb Used in Airstrike on Yemen Wedding - bellingcat|date=27 April 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
In November 2018, a Bellingcat investigation on [[Houthi]] broadcasts through their affiliated [[Almasirah]] news channel of missile attacks targeted against [[United Arab Emirates]] (UAE) airports the [[Abu Dhabi International Airport]] and [[Dubai International Airport]] was published. The investigation report concluded that "It is highly likely that a Houthi-led drone attack did not take place in Abu Dhabi or Dubai".<ref name="BY">{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/mena/2018/11/07/investigating-houthi-claims-drone-attacks-uae-airports/|title=Investigating Houthi Claims of Drone Attacks on UAE Airports|author=Khalil Dewan|publisher=bellingcat.com|date=7 November 2018}}</ref> According to the report, the claims of the attacks constituted a a propaganda effort and followed a "propaganda pattern" claims by the [[Houthi]] leaders.<ref name="BY"></ref>
===Skripal poisoning=== {{main|Poisoning of Sergei and Yulia Skripal}} Following [[RT (TV network)|RT]]'s interview with the suspects of the Sergei Skripal poisoning case, Bellingcat published the suspects’ passport data showing inconsistencies in the official story, and possible links to the Russian secret service. The Russian foreign ministry rejected the report stating that it believed Bellingcat had ties to western intelligence. It noted Bellingcat's access to a Russian database not publicly available.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2018/09/14/skripal-poisoning-suspects-passport-data-shows-link-security-services/|title=Skripal Poisoning Suspect's Passport Data Shows Link to Security Services - bellingcat|date=14 September 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/sep/15/documents-show-novichok-salisbury-suspects-alexander-petrov-ruslan-boshirov-links-defence|title=Documents reveal Salisbury poisoning suspects' Russian defence ministry ties|first=Andrew|last=Roth|date=15 September 2018|website=the Guardian}}</ref> Shortly after, the website said it had identified one of the suspects as decorated [[GRU]] [[colonel]] [[Anatoliy Chepiga]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/26/salisbury-poisoning-suspect-is-russian-colonel-reports|title=Salisbury poisoning suspect identified as Russian colonel|first1=Andrew|last1=Roth|first2=Vikram|last2=Dodd|date=26 September 2018|website=the Guardian|accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref>
==Awards== In 2015, Eliot Higgins and Bellingcat received the special prize of the [[Hanns-Joachim-Friedrichs-Award]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hanns-joachim-friedrichs.de/index.php/pressemitteilung-2015.html |title=Pressemitteilung 2015 - Hanns-Joachim-Friedrichs-Preis |website=Hanns-joachim-friedrichs.de |date= |accessdate=2016-12-24}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox civil conflict | title = Bersih 5 rally | partof = [[Bersih rally (disambiguation)|Bersih rally]] | image = Bersih 5 Logo.jpg | caption = Logo of the rally used by Bersih organisers | date = 19 November 2016 | place = [[Jalan Bangsar]] to [[Dataran Merdeka]], [[Kuala Lumpur]]
''(Bersih Convoy: [[Kangar]], [[Johor Bahru]], [[Kota Bahru]], [[Lumut, Malaysia|Lumut]], [[Sandakan]] and [[Miri, Malaysia|Miri]])'' | coordinates = | causes = | status = Held | goals = * For a New [[Malaysia]] * Free and Fair [[Election]]s * A Clean [[Government]] * The Right to [[Dissent]] * Strengthening the [[Parliamentary Democracy]] * Empowering [[Sabah]] and [[Sarawak]] * Resignation of Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]]{{cite web|title=Former Malaysian PM Mahathir Mohamad urges citizens to join protest against Najib Razak|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-16/mahathir-urges-malaysians-to-join-protest-against-najib/8031864|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=17 November 2016}} | methods = | side1 = [[Bersih]] | side2 = Red Shirts
Orange Shirts{{cite web|title=After Red Shirts, Now These Orange Shirts Want To Join The Anti-Bersih Bandwagon|url=http://says.com/my/news/orange-shirt-malaysia-makkal-sakti-party|website=SAYS.com|accessdate=19 November 2016}} | side3 = [[Royal Malaysia Police]] | leadfigures1 = [[Maria Chin Abdullah]] (detained)
[[Bersih|The Bersih Steering Committee]]
[[Mahathir Mohamad]] | leadfigures2 = Jamal Yunos (detained){{cite news|title=Malaysian PM Najib warns protesters over violence ahead of demonstration|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/malaysian-pm-najib-warns-protesters-over-violence-ahead-of/3296304.html|accessdate=17 November 2016|work=Channel NewsAsia|publisher=CNA|date=17 November 2016}}
Datuk R.S. Thanenthiran (MMSP president) | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = 40,000 (Media estimate)
15,000 (Police estimate){{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/thousands-hold-anti-pm-rally-malaysia-17-detained-090227108.html|title=Thousands rally calling on Malaysian prime minister to quit}}
1,400 Bersih security personnel | howmany2 = 2,500–4,000 | howmany3 = 7,000 officers{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/7-000-police-to-be-deployed-for-bersih-rally/3301028.html|title=7,000 police to be deployed for Bersih rally}} | arrests = 12+ | notes = }} [[File:Bersih 5 on 19 November 2016.jpg|thumb|KLCC on 19 November 2016]] [[File:Bersih 5.jpg|thumb]] The '''Bersih 5 rally''' (also known by its tagline: '''Combine our energy – New Malaysia'''){{cite web|title=Bersih 5 rally set for Nov 19|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/1971236|publisher=The Sun Daily|accessdate=15 September 2016}} was a peaceful democratic protest in Malaysia, supported by the [[Bersih|Coalition for Clean and Fair Elections]] (Bersih), which took place on 19 November 2016. The rally was held calling for a new and cleaner electoral system in [[Malaysia]]. A Bersih convoy was also launched and targeted all parts of Malaysia to raise awareness of the current democratic problems nationwide.{{cite web|title=Why Bersih is marching for the fifth time on Nov 19 - Malaysiakini|url=https://www.malaysiakini.com/news/355714|publisher=Malaysia Kini|accessdate=15 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Maria Chin: Bersih 5 in November|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/maria-chin-bersih-5-in-november|publisher=The Malay Mail|accessdate=15 September 2016|date=7 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Bersih 5 on November 19|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/bersih-5-on-november-19|publisher=The Malay Mail|accessdate=15 September 2016|date=14 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Bersih 5 rally set for Nov 19|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/09/14/bersih-5-rally-set-for-nov-19/|publisher=The Star|accessdate=15 September 2016}} == Background == Incumbent Malaysian Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]] has denied any wrongdoing amidst the ongoing [[1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal]] and former premier Mahathir Mohamad has come out in support of pro Bersih campaigners.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/1mdb-scandal-around-malaysian-prime-minister-najib-puts-spotlight-on-wife-1473606895|title=1MDB Scandal Around Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Puts Spotlight on Wife|first=Tom|last=Wright|date=12 September 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016|via=Wall Street Journal}} Steven Gan, an editor of an online news website [[Malaysiakini]] was charged in court under the [[Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission|Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission Act]] for the reporting of Prime Minister Najib and 1Malaysia Development Berhad, leading up to the rally.{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/2047318/editor-charged-malaysia-over-1mdb-coverage-eve-huge-anti|title=Editor charged in Malaysia over 1MDB coverage on eve of huge anti-government rally|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://english.astroawani.com/malaysia-news/bersih-5-five-things-you-need-know-122128|title=Bersih 5 Five things you need to know|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|title=Bersih 5 convoy gets warm welcome at Balai Ringin|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2016/10/31/bersih-5-convoy-gets-warm-welcome-at-balai-ringin/|accessdate=19 November 2016|date=30 October 2016}} === Red Shirts === The Red Shirts were basically formed to opposed the activities of Bersih, especially its criticisms of the government and to support the government.{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/red-shirts-gather-to-counter-bersih-5-rally|title=Red Shirts gather to counter Bersih 5 rally|date=19 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} Many members of the Red Shirts consists of [[United Malay National Organisation|UMNO]], which is the ruling party in Malaysia.{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/363203|title=S’gor Umno info chief and his kids will join the red-shirts|date=17 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/2062828|title=Umno will not stop its members from joining Red Shirts group (Updated) - theSundaily|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2016/11/16/umno-powerless-to-stop-members-from-wearing-red-shirts/|title=Umno powerless to stop members from wearing red shirts|date=16 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} The pro government group led by Jamal Yunos indicates that the Red Shirts will confront the yellow shirt Bersih protesters during the stipulated rally on 19 November 2016. In a prelude encounter, Jamal Yunos was injured with his nose bloodied in [[Ampang, Kuala Lumpur|Ampang]] during a filmed scuffle with the police, with Jamal shouting that he was punched by the police.{{cite web|title=Jamal Yunos left with bloodied nose|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/11/13/jamal-bloodied-nose-ampang/|accessdate=19 November 2016}} He later changed his statement because he was threatened by the government, claiming he was punched by a Bersih supporter. === Participants === {{empty section|date=June 2017}} == Pre-rally plans == === Bersih convoy === Bersih organised a convoy of vehicles to tour parts of Peninsula Malaysia and the states of Sabah and Sarawak to disseminate information to the public about the Bersih's goals regarding institutional reforms and creating awareness about the 1MDB scandal.{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/10/182740/bersih-5-convoy-causes-barely-stir-pahang|title=Bersih 5 convoy causes barely a stir in Pahang|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} Throughout their nationwide roadshow in Peninsula Malaysia, the Bersih convoy had to endure harassment from anti-Bersih groups such as the Red Shirts and the police.{{cite web|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2016/11/11/sarawak-bersih-convoy-peaceful-as-theres-no-umno/|title=Sarawak Bersih convoy peaceful as there's no Umno|date=11 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/11/188318/man-recorded-hurling-racist-remarks-bersih-5-convoy-under-investigation|title=Man recorded hurling racist remarks at Bersih 5 convoy under investigation|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/360116|title=Politics could be derailing Bersih convoy in Selangor|date=23 October 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} == Pre-rally arrests == The Malaysian police, during their raid on Bersih's office in [[Petaling Jaya]] arrested Bersih chairperson [[Maria Chin Abdullah]] and secretariat Mandeep Singh for their part in organising the rally.{{cite web|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2016/11/18/police-arrests-maria-chin-after-bersih-raid/|title=Police arrest Maria Chin after Bersih raid|date=18 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/11/189909/bersih-rally-go-or-without-maria-chin|title=Bersih rally to go on, with or without Maria Chin|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} Maria Chin was charged under the [[Security Offences (Special Measures) Act 2012|Security Offences Act 2012]], with the police saying that it was to prevent riots and breach of the peace and public order.{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/maria-chin-detained-under-sosma|title=Maria Chin detained under Sosma|date=19 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} [[Ronnie Liu]], an opposition leader of the [[Democratic Action Party (Malaysia)|Democratic Action Party]] was arrested as well on charges on attempting a riot.{{cite web|title=Ronnie Liu arrested ahead of Bersih 5 rally|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/2065596|accessdate=19 November 2016}} Anthony Loke, another member of DAP was also arrested in an investigation on his speech calling for the removal of Prime Minister Najib.{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/363324|title=Cops detain DAP's Anthony Loke and Ronnie Liu|date=18 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} S Arulchelvan, an opposition leader from [[Parti Sosialis Malaysia]] was arrested in [[Brickfields]], Kuala Lumpur.{{cite web|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2016/11/18/psms-arulchelvan-arrested-on-way-to-his-office/|title=PSM's Arulchelvan arrested on way to his office|date=18 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} Another member of the Bersih committee, [[Hishamuddin Rais]] was arrested a few hours before the rally began.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysia-arrests-activist-hishamuddin-rais-as-thousands-join-anti-govt-protests|title=Malaysia arrests activist Hishamuddin Rais as thousands join anti-govt protests|date=19 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} Bersih officials have condemned the arrest as a blatant abuse of power and harassment by the authorities.{{cite web|url=http://www.benarnews.org/english/news/malaysian/bersih-arrests-11182016164235.html|title=On Eve of Mass Protest, Malaysia Arrests Rally Leaders|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0d563386-acad-11e6-9cb3-bb8207902122|title=Subscribe to read|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} The leader of the Red Shirts, a group opposing Bersih and their Yellow Shirt followers, Jamal Yunos was arrested a few hours before the Bersih rally began.{{cite web|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2016/11/19/cops-arrest-red-shirts-leader-jamal-yunos-from-hotel/|title=Cops arrest Red Shirts leader Jamal Yunos|date=19 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} == Rally incidents == The counter-rally by the Red Shirts ended prematurely after they were unable to get past the police blockade to confront the Bersih rally-goers, with a majority of them dispersing at Padang Merbok.{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/11/190097/red-shirts-regrouping-padang-merbok|title=Red Shirts regrouping at Padang Merbok|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2016/11/19/red-shirts-disperse-leaving-padang-merbok-in-a-mess/|title=Red Shirts disperse, leaving Padang Merbok in a mess|date=19 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} == Aftermath == Even though the protests ended peacefully, the arrests against Bersih protestors such as [[People's Justice Party (Malaysia)|People's Justice Party (Malaysia)'s]] [[Chua Tian Chang|Tian Chua]] and [[Zuraida Kamaruddin]] were conducted.http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2016/11/20/tian-chua-and-zuraida-arrested/http://english.astroawani.com/malaysia-news/bersih-5-tian-chua-zuraida-detained-police-123143 == Reactions == === Prime Minister === Then Prime Minister Datuk Seri [[Najib Razak]] who was in Tokyo, said that Malaysians should respect the law and avoid chaos and physical clashes. He also claimed that Malaysians should elect their leaders without having to protest as it was not Malaysia's culture, despite the fact that right of peaceful assembly (which Bersih exercised) is legally provided for in Malaysia.{{cite web|title=Avoid chaos, Najib says ahead of Bersih|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/11/189284/avoid-chaos-najib-says-ahead-bersih|website=NST Online|accessdate=19 November 2016}} === Malaysian Police === Inspector General of Police, Khalid Abu Bakar stated that Bersih 5 does not fulfil the Section 10(c) and Section 11 of [[Peaceful Assembly Act 2012]] as there was no consent letter was produced for the venue of the rally, Dataran Merdeka.{{cite web|title=IGP: Bersih 5 doesn't fulfil rules of Peaceful Assembly Act|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2016/11/08/igp-bersih-5-doesnt-fulfil-rules-of-peaceful-assembly-act/|website=Free Malaysia Today|accessdate=19 November 2016|date=8 November 2016}} === Non-governmental organisations === [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Amnesty International]] have condemned the spate of arrests by the government of Malaysian activists as a form of intimidation and harassment against dissent.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/news/aec/30300361|title=Protesters gather in Malaysia's capital for anti-government rally - The Nation|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://mysinchew.com/node/116125?tid=4|title=Malaysiakini editor charged amidst press freedom fears|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/11/malaysia-end-crackdown-on-bersih-activists/|title=Malaysia: End crackdown on Bersih activists|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2016}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.bersih.org/ Bersih 2.0] * [http://www.globalbersih.org/ Global Bersih] {{Malaysian protests and rallies}} {{Anti-government protests in the 21st century}} [[Category:2016 in Malaysia]] [[Category:2016 protests]] [[Category:Civil rights protests]] [[Category:Electoral reform in Malaysia]] [[Category:November 2016 events in Asia]] [[Category:Protest marches]] [[Category:Protests in Malaysia]]

[http://the17.org/ The17]
